author: S Poorvaja
text:
With over 240 book stalls, the Pongal Book Festival organised by the Tamil Book Sales Promotion Association at the YMCA Grounds in Royapettah, promises to be a treat for book lovers in the city.

Inaugurating the festival on Wednesday evening, Gopalkrishna Gandhi, former Governor of West Bengal said the rising intolerance in the country, which had an impact on intellectual freedom, was a cause for concern.

“In recent years, extreme religious fundamentalism has been posing a threat to rational thought which has in turn impacted writing and publishing. Tamil Nadu has always championed intellectual liberty, but recent examples of the way writer Perumal Murugan and singer Kovan were treated are warning signs of the things to come,” he said.

Justice K. Chandru, Former Judge of Madras HC said he hoped to see an increase in patronage for the book festival here.

“This is an important time to promote reading, writing and freedom of creative expression. Over the last year, we saw a number of authors return their Sahitya Akademi awards in protest against rising intolerance in the country. In the state too, there were a few written works which came under fire from various quarters,” Mr Chandru recalled.

The Book festival is on till January 23.

R.S. Shanmugam, trustee of the association said the proceeds will go towards flood relief. “A few publishers did not want to postpone the festival and deny the opportunity to book lovers during the festive season which is why we organised this in the span of ten days,” he said.
title: ‘Rising intolerance, a threat to rational thought, creativity’
